docs.lead_paragraph: Google's mission to compete with Facebook in social networking may be gaining speed. On Tuesday Paul Allen, a researcher, published an analysis saying that Google+, the company's social networking service, has reached 62 million registered users. More important, one-quarter of all users signed up in December alone, he said, putting it on a path to sustained global growth.

headline.main: Google Plus Gains More Traction, Researcher Says

headline.main: The Breakfast Meeting: Iowa Under the Microscope and China vs. the West

docs.abstract: Romney vs. Santorum proves to be Ali/Frazier for the media, China reinforces limits on Western cultural products and Google punishes itself.

docs.snippet: Romney vs. Santorum proves to be Ali/Frazier for the media, China reinforces limits on Western cultural products and Google punishes itself....
docs.lead_paragraph: Just when you thought the intense news analysis of the presidential choices of 120,000 Iowa Republicans couldn't get any more granular, Tuesday night's caucuses produced a result that, as news anchors are fond of saying, showed that "each vote counts." It was thrilling stuff for the anchors, who enjoyed the tension, as Brian Stelter writes. "We have no idea when we'll be able to call this," Rachel Maddow said at 10 p.m. "It's great." The cable networks continued on toward 3 a.m. Eastern, after Mitt Romney was declared the winner by eight votes - though, helpfully, he was ahead by a 10th of a decimal point, 24.6 percent vs. 24.5 percent for Rick Santorum.

headline.main: The Breakfast Meeting: Iowa Under the Microscope and China vs. the West

docs.abstract: Romney vs. Santorum proves to be Ali/Frazier for the media, China reinforces limits on Western cultural products and Google punishes itself.

headline.print_headline: Internet Access Is Not a Human Right

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Google vice president Vinton G Cerf contends that the Internet has emerged as a powerful tool for democracy in the Arab world and elsewhere, but it still does not qualify as a human right; asserts technology is an enabler of rights, not a right in itself; says engineers and technologists still have an obligation to ensure the safety of users online.

keywords.value: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

docs.snippet: Both Samsung and HTC have been aggressive advocates of Google's Android operating system. Samsung's profits rose while HTC's profits sank. Their divergent performances illustrate the vast effort it takes to remain successful in the highly competit...
docs.lead_paragraph: Samsung Electronics on Friday posted record fourth-quarter profits, citing high sales of its Android devices, while HTC, another major Android player, reported a drop in profits, its first decline in two years.Samsung, based in Seoul, South Korea, said its profits increased 73 percent compared to 2010's fourth quarter. It cited record-breaking sales of its smartphones, as well as the sale of its hard drive business to Seagate.

headline.main: HTC's Decline Is Samsung's Gain

docs.snippet: One day after leaving the United States national team's training camp in Arizona for ''club-related reasons,'' Los Angeles Galaxy defender Omar Gonzalez flew to Germany and on Thursday agreed to a short-term loan with Nuremberg of the Bundesliga. ...
docs.lead_paragraph: One day after leaving the United States national team's training camp in Arizona for ''club-related reasons,'' Los Angeles Galaxy defender Omar Gonzalez flew to Germany and on Thursday agreed to a short-term loan with Nuremberg of the Bundesliga. ''We are delighted that Omar has traveled with us in training camp,'' the Nuremberg spokesman Martin Bader said on the club's Web site in a Google translation from German. ''We were considering having him join us in summer 2012 but we have got the opportunity to loan him at least until the start of the M.L.S. season.'' He added, ''Omar is an interesting candidate, a young, talented player who could be a good fit for 1.FC Nurnberg.''

headline.main: Galaxy Defender Loaned

docs.abstract: Los Angeles Galaxy defender Omar Gonzalez agrees to a short-term loan with Nuremberg of the German soccer league Bundesliga; other soccer news noted. (M)

docs.snippet: The International Consumer Electronics Show has long enjoyed a central role in taking the pulse of the tech industry. But as the industry has changed, so has the significance of C.E.S....
docs.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS -- The International Consumer Electronics Show has long enjoyed a central role in taking the pulse of the tech industry. But Microsoft recently announced that it would no longer exhibit at the show after this year. Other tech giants like Hewlett-Packard, Google and Facebook are keeping a low profile at the show, if they bother to show up at all. It all reflects shifts in the tech industry, as Nick Wingfield reported in Monday's New York Times.

headline.main: Video: The Changing Nature of the Consumer Electronics Show

docs.abstract: The International Consumer Electronics Show has long enjoyed a central role in taking the pulse of the tech industry. But as the industry has changed, so has the significance of C.E.S.

docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO - Google's popularity was built on its ability to help people find just the right Web pages. Then came the social Web, led by Facebook, where people go to see vast amounts of material that has largely been off-limits to Google - conversations and photos posted by their friends.

headline.main: Google Adds Posts From Its Social Network to Search Results

docs.abstract: In what it says is one of the biggest changes to its search results, Google will begin showing posts, photos, profiles and conversations from Google+, its social network, in search results. The new feature comes as Google risks losing its status as the Web's front door to Facebook.

docs.snippet: Monday was a big day for smartphones at the International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. AT&T talked about new smartphones that would run on its fast 4G network, including the Titan II from HTC. And Nokia, as expected, unveiled the Lumia ...

headline.main: Daily Report: Nokia and Microsoft Unveil an Ambitious Phone

docs.abstract:
Monday was a big day for smartphones at the International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. AT&T talked about new smartphones that would run on its fast 4G network, including the Titan II from HTC. And Nokia, as expected, unveiled the Lumia 900, Nick Wingfield reported from the show. That phone, which runs Microsoft’s Windows Phone operating system, represents a bid by Microsoft and Nokia to return to relevance in the smartphone market, after being marginalized by Apple and Google’s Android system.

The initial buzz about the Lumia 900 among gadget-watchers has been positive. Stephen Elop, the chief executive of Nokia, said the company had put all of its best technology into the phone. “It’s the first real Windows Phone built for and designed for the North American market,” he said. The phone will also run on the AT&T 4G network and will be exclusive to AT&T in the United States.

Our coverage of the show is on our personal tech blog, Gadgetwise. Some highlights from Monday:

— The London Olympics, Coming in 3-D

— Video: The Changing Nature of C.E.S.

— Intel Pushes MacBook Air-Like Notebooks, but for Windows

— Talking to the Television to Tune In a Show

— A Thinner Smartphone from Huawei

— Google TV Tries Again

AT&T talked about new smartphones that would run on its fast 4G network, including the Titan II from HTC. And Nokia, as expected, unveiled the Lumia 900, Nick Wingfield reported from the show. That phone, which runs Microsoft's Windows Phone operating system, represents a bid by Microsoft and Nokia to return to relevance in the smartphone market, after being marginalized by Apple and Google's Android system.

headline.main: Daily Report: Nokia and Microsoft Unveil an Ambitious Phone

docs.snippet: While the International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas is for, well, consumer electronics, a number of items were displayed that will be making their way into the workplace. And we aren’t just talking about the spate of ultrabooks, those...

headline.main: Daily Report: Enterprise Computing at C.E.S.

docs.abstract:
While the International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas is for, well, consumer electronics, a number of items were displayed that will be making their way into the workplace. And we aren’t just talking about the spate of ultrabooks, those lightweight and thin MacBook Air clones, that will be showing up in offices soon.

Nick Wingfield reported on The New York Times’s Gadgetwise blog, where coverage of the gigantic trade show is appearing, that OnLive, a startup, has developed a free app for the iPad that will let users run a Windows 7 desktop on their iPads, including Word, Excel and PowerPoint. Users will be able to create and edit documents in those applications on their iPads and store them online, using the two gigabytes of free storage OnLive will provide people.

Research in Motion, maker of the BlackBerry, announced at the show that it updated the operating system running its PlayBook tablet so that it now runs e-mail, calendar and contacts that enterprise customers need. Gizmodo said it “finally turns the PlayBook into a real tablet.”

Tom Krazit at PaidContent reported that Intel convinced Lenovo and Motorola to release phones and tablets based on its mobile chips in 2012.

Samsung Electronics announced it was refreshing its Chromebooks, a device that Google hopes will be used in the workplace.

Engadget also reported on a desktop phone for businesses that uses the Android operating system, the ESI 250.

docs.snippet: MittRomney's early win leaves anchors scrambling and a dispute between Google and Twitter gets personal....

headline.main: The Breakfast Meeting: The Spielberg Exception and Who's Illin'?

docs.abstract: MittRomney's early win leaves anchors scrambling and a dispute between Google and Twitter gets personal.

docs.snippet: MittRomney's early win leaves anchors scrambling and a dispute between Google and Twitter gets personal....
docs.lead_paragraph: That Mitt Romney's victory in the New Hampshire primary was considered all but assured even before the voting began on Tuesday didn't stop the news coverage from going into overdrive, Brian Stelter reports. But the operation appeared to be running on fumes. Once a winner was crowned -- at 8 p.m., precisely when all polls were closed -- the topic turned to second place. That, too, was over early, with Ron Paul declared the runner-up in that same hour. The focus then turned to South Carolina, and how Mr. Romney would fare in a state that would test his conservative credentials: CNN had already assembled a group of undecided Republicans there, Mr. Stelter writes, while Fox News promoted its debate there on Monday.

headline.main: The Breakfast Meeting: The Spielberg Exception and Who's Illin'?

docs.abstract: MittRomney's early win leaves anchors scrambling and a dispute between Google and Twitter gets personal.

docs.snippet: SAN FRANCISCO - Google's popularity was built on its ability to help people find just the right Web pages. Then came the social Web, led by Facebook, where people go to see vast amounts of material that has largely been off-limits to Google - conv...
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO - Google's popularity was built on its ability to help people find just the right Web pages. Then came the social Web, led by Facebook, where people go to see vast amounts of material that has largely been off-limits to Google - conversations and photos posted by their friends. On Tuesday, Google sparked controversy when it made some of the biggest changes ever to its search results, adding content from its fledgling Google Plus social network. That includes posts, photos, profiles and conversations from Google Plus that are public or were shared privately with the person searching.

headline.main: Google Adds Social Network to Search Results

docs.abstract: Google adds content from its Google Plus social network, including posts, photos, profiles and conversations, to its search results; company is reimagining what people want from its search engine, betting that users are looking for more personalized and timely updates as it competes with Facebook and others in a changing online landscape; critics say new results will be cluttered and raise privacy concerns. Photo (M)

byline.original: By CLAIRE CAIN MILLER; Nick Bilton contributed reporting

headline.main: Google's New Search Results Raise Privacy and Antitrust Concerns

docs.abstract: Google's decision to add Google Plus posts and profiles to search results this week prompted a backlash from some people in the technology, privacy and antitrust worlds. Some have said that it violates users' privacy for personal posts to show up in search results, and others say Google is favoring its own social network over competitors.

headline.main: One on One: Stephen Elop, Nokia Chief

docs.abstract: Stephen Elop, the chief executive of Nokia,  the Finnish cellphone maker, has a difficult challenge ahead to restore the company's credibility in the American market, where Google's Android and Apple's iPhone are thriving. In an interview, he says he's betting that using Microsoft's Windows Phone operating system on its devices will help with a turnaround.

docs.snippet: Stephen Elop, the chief executive of Nokia, the Finnish cellphone maker, has a difficult challenge ahead to restore the company's credibility in the American market, where Google's Android and Apple's iPhone are thriving. In an interview, he says ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Stephen A. Elop, the chief executive of Nokia, the Finnish cellphone maker, has a difficult challenge ahead to restore the company's credibility in the American market, where Google's Android and Apple's iPhone are thriving. He's betting that using Microsoft's Windows Phone operating system on its devices will help with a turnaround. The following are edited excerpts of an interview from earlier this week at the International Consumer Electronics Show after Mr. Elop introduced a new phone that will be sold by AT&T, the Lumia 900:

In an interview, he says he's betting that using Microsoft's Windows Phone operating system on its devices will help with a turnaround.

docs.snippet: A lawsuit in India demands that Internet companies screen content posted on sites like Facebook, Google or Yahoo, that might offend the religious sentiments of Indians. A related criminal case accuses the companies -- 21 in all -- of violating an ...

headline.main: India Grapples With Web Censorship

docs.abstract: A lawsuit in India demands that Internet companies screen content posted on sites like Facebook, Google or Yahoo, that might offend the religious sentiments of Indians. A related criminal case accuses the companies -- 21 in all -- of violating an Indian law that applies to books, pamphlets and other material that is deemed to "deprave or corrupt."

docs.snippet: A lawsuit in India demands that Internet companies screen content posted on sites like Facebook, Google or Yahoo, that might offend the religious sentiments of Indians. A related criminal case accuses the companies -- 21 in all -- of violating an ...
docs.lead_paragraph: India has long faced an uneasy tension between allowing free expression to its citizens and staunching sectarian violence among its people. It was one of the first countries to ban "The Satanic Verses" by Salman Rushdie. Lawsuits forced the Indian painter Maqbool Fida Husain to live in exile during the last several years of his life. An academic book about the 17th-century warrior known as Shivaji was banned for fear of offending Shivaji's modern-day fans, until the Supreme Court lifted the prohibition.

headline.main: India Grapples With Web Censorship

docs.abstract: A lawsuit in India demands that Internet companies screen content posted on sites like Facebook, Google or Yahoo, that might offend the religious sentiments of Indians. A related criminal case accuses the companies -- 21 in all -- of violating an Indian law that applies to books, pamphlets and other material that is deemed to "deprave or corrupt."

docs.snippet: Television networks' parent companies support antipiracy legislation, which critics argue would censor the Internet, and TV news shows have generally ignored the issue....
docs.lead_paragraph: A pair of bills that would strengthen antipiracy laws - and that could essentially censor the Internet, according to heavyweights like Google - have received scant coverage from the major television networks. The parent companies of the TV networks are among the chief supporters of the bills, having lobbied Congress to write them in the first place.

headline.main: A TV Debate on Antipiracy

docs.abstract: Television networks' parent companies support antipiracy legislation, which critics argue would censor the Internet, and TV news shows have generally ignored the issue.

docs.snippet: In the growing business of electronic medical records, Epic Systems is far from a newcomer: it started more than 30 years ago, and now helps keep track of 40 million patients....
docs.lead_paragraph: Epic Systems supplies electronic records for large health care providers like the Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, the Cleveland Clinic and Johns Hopkins Medicine in Baltimore. A treehouse for meetings? A two-story spiral slide just for fun? What's that big statue of the Cat in the Hat doing here? Epic's reputation as a fun-filled, creative place to work helps draw programmers who might otherwise take jobs at Google, Microsoft or Facebook, reports Milt Freudenheim in The New York Times.Read more » .

headline.main: Digitizing Health Records, Before It Was Cool

docs.abstract: In the growing business of electronic medical records, Epic Systems is far from a newcomer: it started more than 30 years ago, and now helps keep track of 40 million patients.

docs.snippet: A pair of bills that would strengthen antipiracy laws - and that could essentially censor the Internet, according to heavyweights like Google - have received scant coverage from the major television networks. The parent companies of the TV network...
docs.lead_paragraph: A pair of bills that would strengthen antipiracy laws - and that could essentially censor the Internet, according to heavyweights like Google - have received scant coverage from the major television networks. The parent companies of the TV networks are among the chief supporters of the bills, having lobbied Congress to write them in the first place. Those two facts, taken together, have caused conspiracy theories to flourish online about corporate interference in news coverage.

headline.main: A TV Debate on Antipiracy

docs.abstract: Media Decoder blog notes parent companies of major television networks support antipiracy legislation, criticized as censoring the Internet; says fact that television news shows have all but ignored the issue has led to conspiracy theories about corporate interference in news coverage to flourish online. (M)

docs.snippet: Also, a new urgency and speed among films at Sundance, and China wants to require all microbloggers to reveal their identities before being allowed to post comments....
docs.lead_paragraph: Wednesday is a day of Web-wide protest over proposed antipiracy laws. Some sites, like Google and Craigslist are donning black and encouraging visitors to contact their local members of Congress (both are still operating, however). Others, most notably the English-language Wikipedia portal, have closed for the day, while also asking visitors to lobby Congress.

headline.main: The Breakfast Meeting: Wikipedia Turns Off the Lights

docs.snippet: The battle over two Congressional bills intended to prevent copyright violations on the Internet marks a political coming of age for the tech industry, reports Jenna Wortham in Wednesday’s New York Times. The relatively young and politically dis...

headline.main: Daily Report: A Political Coming of Age for the Tech Industry

docs.abstract:
The battle over two Congressional bills intended to prevent copyright violations on the Internet marks a political coming of age for the tech industry, reports Jenna Wortham in Wednesday’s New York Times. The relatively young and politically disorganized tech industry has found its voice in opposing the bills, which it says would go too far — potentially violating free speech and stifling innovation — by allowing media companies to shut down Web sites they say are abusing copyrights. It’s an issue that has led to a rare show of unity for the industry’s players — from venture capitalists to the smallest Web sites.

The bills have been shelved for the time being, but the industry is not letting up in trying to sway public opinion. On Wednesday, a Web-wide protest includes a 24-hour shutdown of the English-language Wikipedia site. The main pages of several other sites, including Google, Craigslist and Wired, also reflect their opposition to the bills. Rallies are planned Wednesday in New York, San Francisco and Seattle. And in Washington the lobbying remains fierce from both supporters and opponents of the legislation.

Around the Web, the controversy over the bills and the protests also received wide attention. At The Atlantic Megan Garber wrote about the discussion within Wikipedia that led to the discussion to shut down. On Mashable, Chris Heald analyzed the legislation in detail to explain the arguments against it. Meanwhile, The New Yorker directed readers to the poet John Milton’s defense of free speech before the English Parliament in 1644.

docs.snippet: Washington’s old guard of media lobbyists — including the United States Chamber of Commerce, the Recording Industry Association of America and the motion picture lobby — was forced to make way for the new on Wednesday as Web powerhouses back...

headline.main: Daily Report: A New Power Hits Washington

docs.abstract:
Washington’s old guard of media lobbyists — including the United States Chamber of Commerce, the Recording Industry Association of America and the motion picture lobby — was forced to make way for the new on Wednesday as Web powerhouses backed by Internet activists rallied opposition to antipiracy legislation by using Internet blackouts and cascading criticism, reports Jonathan Weisman from Washington. He said it sent an unmistakable message to lawmakers grappling with new media issues: Don’t mess with the Internet.

Jenna Wortham, a technology reporter at The New York Times, explains how that happened:

Some sites blacked out — among them, the English-language Wikipedia, though it was possible to access the encyclopedia through several clever workarounds — while others, including Google and Craigslist, draped their pages with information about the bills, or restricted access.

Many start-ups quickly cobbled together tech solutions to support their cause. HelloFax, for example, created a tool that let people send their representatives faxes voicing their opinions through the Web.

The effort was an unusual orchestration that began gathering steam online late Tuesday night and escalated early Wednesday morning, eventually whipping the Web into a frenzy.

Around the Web, others chronicled what was happening. The Los Angeles Times Technology Blog reported that 4.5 million people signed an anti-SOPA petition.

Dan Seitz at Uproxx reported that the motion picture industry’s lobbying group “hits new low in self pity.”

And as Wikipedia said very early Thursday morning as it returned to service: “We’re Not Done Yet.”

headline.main: Online Piracy and Political Overreach

docs.abstract: Editorial welcomes reduced Congressional support for the Stop online Piracy Act and Protect I P Act following an extraordinary outcry from Internet users, led by Google and Wikipedia; expresses hope that lawmakers will now have time to consider bills' implications and act wisely to create tools that can reduce online piracy without excessive collateral damage to legitimate Web sites.

docs.snippet: Joining its hometown industry and betting on the success of YouTube's new initiative to promote original content, the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles announced that it would start an online video channel in July featuring news and talk-s...
docs.lead_paragraph: Joining its hometown industry and betting on the success of YouTube's new initiative to promote original content, the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles announced that it would start an online video channel in July featuring news and talk-show programming, among other art-focused shows. MOCA TV, as the channel will be known, will be the first contemporary-art channel to be included as part of YouTube's plan, announced last October, to move more aggressively onto the turf of network and cable television by creating dozens of channels featuring comedy, sports, music and other kinds of entertainment. YouTube, a unit of Google, has already announced programming partnerships with the likes of The Wall Street Journal, Thomson Reuters, and WWE, the wrestling producer, as well as the production companies of celebrities like Madonna, Rainn Wilson, and Shaquille O'Neal.

headline.main: Museum to Start YouTube Channel

docs.abstract: Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art will start an online video channel as part of YouTube's initiative to promote original content. (M)

docs.snippet: YouSendIt, Dropbox, and services from Amazon and Google market themselves as ways to store content. But they are ideal for anyone looking to illegitimately share copyrighted video and audio files....
docs.lead_paragraph: Cloud services market themselves as legitimate ways to store content online. But they are inherently ideal for anyone looking to illegitimately upload and share copyrighted video and audio files, report Nicole Perlroth and Quentin Hardy of the The New York Times. Most companies rarely, if ever, inspect individual files to see if the material they store on behalf of users violates copyrights. Read more »

docs.lead_paragraph: For all the change whirling about the entertainment business (technological and other), the Oscar nominations announced Tuesday morning send an incongruous message: nothing has changed. Parsing the nine best picture nominees, Michael Cieply finds some recurring patterns: no animation (though, with "Hugo," a 3-D movie was included); all but one from a major studio or a specialty division of same ("The Artist" is the exception); the settings are more past than present. He continues:

docs.snippet: 8:15 p.m. | Updated Google said Tuesday that it would revise its privacy policies and terms of service, to make them shorter and more readable and to change the way Google can use information that users provide.      To alert users about the chang...
docs.lead_paragraph: 8:15 p.m. | Updated Google said Tuesday that it would revise its privacy policies and terms of service, to make them shorter and more readable and to change the way Google can use information that users provide. To alert users about the changes, which take effect March 1, Google plans to undertake its biggest notification effort ever via e-mail and announcements on its various sites, according to a person briefed on Google's plans.

headline.main: A New Policy On Privacy From Google

docs.abstract: Google is revamping its privacy policies and terms of serve to allow it to share users' information across all of the search giant's offerings; changes are part of a continuing mission to unify Google's services and compete with other tech companies like Facebook and Apple to become a one-stop destination for Internet users; changes immediately draw criticism from privacy advocates. (M)

docs.snippet: A technology under development would instruct the Chevrolet Volt to charge only when the grid was pumping a percentage of energy from renewable resources....
docs.lead_paragraph: On Thursday, General Motors announced an alert system under development that would instruct the Chevy Volt to charge only when a relatively high percentage of renewable energy was available. Being plugged in at those times would further minimize the carbon footprint of the plug-in hybrid. Google plans to test the technology, facilitated by the subscription-based OnStar alert and navigation system, on its fleet of 17 Volts.

docs.lead_paragraph: While Web-based companies like Facebook and Google are scouring the world for new talent to hire, older technology workers often find that their skills are no longer valued, reports Aaron Glantz of the Bay Area Citizen and The New York Times. Part of the problem, analysts said, is that many of the companies shedding jobs are technology manufacturers, while most of the companies that are hiring are Internet-based. Read more »

headline.seo: Honda Begins Deliveries of Battery-Powered Fit
headline.main: Honda Begins Deliveries of Battery-Powered Fit
headline.print_headline: Honda Begins Deliveries Of Battery-Powered Fit

docs.abstract: First of the 2013 Honda all-electric Fit EVs are delivered to Google, Stanford University and city of Torrance, Calif, in advance of the public introduction in summer 2012; program will provide advanced research and driving feedback that Honda can use in the development of future electric cars.

docs.snippet: IN the hunt for innovation, that elusive path to economic growth and corporate prosperity, try a little jazz as an inspirational metaphor.     That's the message that John Kao, an innovation adviser to corporations and governments -- who is also a...
docs.lead_paragraph: IN the hunt for innovation, that elusive path to economic growth and corporate prosperity, try a little jazz as an inspirational metaphor. That's the message that John Kao, an innovation adviser to corporations and governments -- who is also a jazz pianist -- was to deliver in a performance and talk on Saturday at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. Jazz, Mr. Kao says, demonstrates some of the tensions in innovation, between training and discipline on one side and improvised creativity on the other.

headline.main: The Yin and the Yang of Corporate Innovation

docs.abstract: Steve Lohr Unboxed column observes that Apple and Google take very different paths to innovation, but the gap between their approaches may be closing a bit; points out the Google model relies on rapid experimentation and data, while the Apple model is more edited, intuitive and top-down. Drawing (M)

headline.main: Does Google+ Offer Businesses an Edge?

docs.abstract: One advantage: it does make it easier to treat different customers differently.

docs.snippet: One advantage: it does make it easier to treat different customers differently....
docs.lead_paragraph: There was a lot of excitement last year when Google+ -- Google's answer to Facebook -- was introduced, because, well, it's Google. But according to everything I've heard and can observe, the great majority of small businesses haven't flocked to the service.

headline.main: Does Google+ Offer Businesses an Edge?

docs.abstract: One advantage: it does make it easier to treat different customers differently.

headline.main: Technology Companies Confront a Scourge of the Internet

docs.abstract: A group of engineers from PayPal, Facebook, Google, Microsoft, Yahoo and other technology firms is introducing a new tool to fight e-mail scams, spoofs and phishing attacks.

docs.snippet: On Monday, an informal working group of engineers from PayPal, Facebook, Google, Microsoft, Yahoo and other technology firms will introduce a new tool to fight e-mail scams, spoofs and phishing attacks. The tool, called Domain-based Message Authen...
docs.lead_paragraph: For all the engineer-poaching and trash-talking going around Silicon Valley these days, there has also been a surprising amount of behind-the-scenes collaboration.

headline.main: Technology Companies Confront a Scourge of the Internet

docs.abstract: On Monday, an informal working group of engineers from PayPal, Facebook, Google, Microsoft, Yahoo and other technology firms will introduce a new tool to fight e-mail scams, spoofs and phishing attacks. The tool, called Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting and Conformance, or DMARC, aims to not only keep malware out of in-boxes, but also get a better sense of the threat landscape: who's behind e-mail scams, where they lurk, how they spoof and who they target.

docs.snippet: ''Most of my life I went to parties and heard a little groan when people heard what I did,'' says Robert Tibshirani, a statistics professor at Stanford University. ''Now they're all excited to meet me.''     It's not because of a new after-shave. ...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''Most of my life I went to parties and heard a little groan when people heard what I did,'' says Robert Tibshirani, a statistics professor at Stanford University. ''Now they're all excited to meet me.'' It's not because of a new after-shave. Arcane statistical analysis, the business of making sense of our growing data mountains, has become high tech's hottest calling. There are billions of bytes generated daily, not just from the Internet but also from sciences like genetics and astronomy. Companies like Google and Facebook, as well as product marketers, risk analysts, spies, natural philosophers and gamblers are all scouring the info, desperate to find a new angle on what makes us and the world tick. Computing has become cheap and available enough to process any number of formulas.

headline.main: The Popularity Of Statistics

docs.abstract: Bits blog observes that statistical analysis has become a hot calling in high technology; points out there is shortage of statisticians. (M)
